awd_titl_txt: CUE Ethics: A Curricular Design Community for Broadening Participation through Computing in the Arts
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to redefine how to teach computer science to students who approach computing from a broader and more diverse set of interests than typical in most programs. These students are not traditional computer science majors but, instead, students who will follow their interests to apply computing to fields as diverse as fine arts, humanities, political science, music, writing, social science, and history, among others. There are many decades of deep integration between arts and technology from which to draw inspiration for new curricular frameworks. The primary objective is to create an educational community consisting of diverse institutions, which will be poised to develop effective Computing in the Arts (CITA) degree programs. Graduates of these CITA programs will create, design, and code new tools for artistic creativity. From contemporary music-, art- and theater-production, to creating new forms of animation, digital media, and games, to invigorating the visual and audio systems of tomorrow's computers, to inventing revolutionary networked applications, the work students do in these collaborative programs will prepare them for computing-aware, productive, and integrated careers in the information and arts economies. While the project concentrates on computing and the arts (e.g., art, music, dance, sculpture, theater), this approach in curricular integration is general and can apply across many fields. CITA curricula have been shown to attract a new, diverse population, including retaining and graduating significantly larger numbers of women. Moreover, by combining art and computing, this curricular approach enhances creativity, design skills, and innovation potential. In this age of social media, immersive and digital art, ubiquitous computing, and new transformative computer-based systems awaiting discovery, this project may have a significant cultural and economic impact on our nation and society.

To achieve these goals, a strong, cohesive, and diverse educational community will be created, consisting of a mid-size liberal arts and sciences university, two research-1 institutions, and a smaller liberal arts college, centered on Computing in the Arts degrees.  A six-year longitudinal study at the lead institution shows that a CITA degree attracts a different student population to computing; attracts and retains almost twice as many female students; and graduates 45.5% women compared to the 19% average in computer science across the nation.  The project will assemble representative Art+CS teams from departments of computer science, art, music, dance and theater at each institution, establish regular online inter-school meetings, and hold at least two meetings at different schools during the grant period to bring the teams together. To strengthen this multi-institutional community, a concrete synthesis activity will be carried out -- a joint, telematic, real-time, four-institution CITA performance project, which will involve students, faculty, and necessary resources to combine motion capture, audience participation, dance, music, and visual art.  Upon completion of this activity, the assembled team aims to be ready to develop Curricular Guidelines for CITA degree programs, to broadly disseminate successes, lessons learned, and methods for broadening participation across the nation, with concrete student and potentially transformative social outcomes.

This IUSE: CUE project is co-funded by EHR/DUE and CISE Directorates CNS, CCF, IIS, and OAC, reflecting the project's alignment with the broader goals of the IUSE: EHR program in DUE and complementary programs in CISE.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project was to develop a vibrant, cohesive, and diverse community of computer scientists and artists, across various institutions, centered on the Computing in the Arts (CITA) degree model (http://cita.cofc.edu).  CITA is an interdisciplinary Bachelor's degree program, developed with earlier NSF funding, which synthesizes core computer science with art theory and practice.  These new CITA programs are recognizing and serving a new generation and a new demographic of students studying computing. These students are quite different from traditional computer science students.  While they learn algorithmic design and computer programming, they are less likely to be tool creators (like traditional CS students).  Instead, they are more likely to use algorithmic process as a new medium for artistic creation and expression, thus broadening participation to computing and its application to other fields and disciplines.  

CITA curricula have been shown to attract a new, diverse population, including retaining and graduating significantly larger numbers of women. Moreover, by combining art and computing, this curricular approach enhances creativity, design skills, and innovation potential. In this age of social media, immersive and digital art, ubiquitous computing, and new transformative computer-based systems awaiting discovery, this project - set in the context of the emerging Algorithmic Arts or AlgoArts movement (http://AlgoArts.org) - may have a significant cultural and economic impact on our nation and society.

This project assembled representative Art+CS teams from departments of computer science, art, music, dance and theater at different institutions. The community of collaborators from the three partner institutions, plus collaborators from 4 additional institutions met (virtually, via Zoom, due to COVID-19) and worked to design a concrete synthesis activity.  Due to COVID, this plan evolved to create a multi-speaker, smartphone-based environment for developing interactive, distributed music and art applications, installations, and experiences. 

This multi-speaker, smartphone-based environment combines "motion capture, audience participation, dance, music, and visual art".   The developed system works well, and has been used to create several artifacts.  It facilitates audience participation via personal smartphones, connecting with traditional computing devices via the Internet, without additional software or special configurations. The developed approach has been inspired / motivated in part by the COVID pandemic and builds on earlier works and technology.

This approach provides a new avenue for music composers and artists to construct highly distributed, participatory, immersive music and art experiences, utilizing various input sensors and actuators available in today's smartphones. This includes smartphone accelerometers, video cameras, and speakers; plus, the ability for geolocation, through GPS or more precise social engineering approaches, such as using dedicated QR codes for different locations (e.g., seats in an auditorium). This allows for artistic and musical experiences to be experienced in the same space (as seen in the examples provided below); to be distributed across the Internet; or a combination of both.  This may inspire new avenues for artistic creativity and expression towards highly immersive, participatory installations / performances of music and art works for the 21st century.

Examples of CS+Art experiences, developed with this environment include:

1.  "Concret PH - A Retelling" (2022) - a recreation of Iannis Xenakis's avant-garde piece, "Concret PH" (1958).  The original was created for the 1958 World's Fair and performed at the Philips Pavilion, using hundreds of speakers.  This recreation utilizes speakers on audience smartphones.  The piece was presented at the University of Maryland, College Park, USA, April 2022 (see https://youtu.be/sCe2qQi_QBY).

2.  "Éolienne PH" (2022) - this experience uses recordings of sounds found in nature to create a restorative, meditative experience.  It is inspired by Iannis Xenakis's 1958 piece, "Concret PH" (see above).  Similarly to its sister piece, it uses audience smartphones to deliver sounds.  Audience members are asked to move around freely.  The piece was performed at the International Symposium on Electronic Art (ISEA 2022), Barcelona, Spain, June 2022 (see https://youtu.be/mNBwNrpwdaA).

3.  "on the Fractal Nature of Being..." (2022) - this experience combines stochastic techniques introduced by Iannis Xenakis with classical music theory, modern mathematics / fractal geometry, and 21st century technology.  The audience participates via smartphones - speakers and accelerometers.  The experience begins with a minute-long musical theme, whose harmony is soon interwoven into a fractal.  The theme is introduced on piano, then repeated by different instruments, at different levels of granularity, for the fractal to unfold.  A Xenakian probability density function guides a continuous transition from consonance to dissonance.  This is best described visually through M.C. Escher's, "Day and Night" (1938).  The piece was composed for the 2022 Meta-Xenakis transcontinental celebration, and performed at the Music Library of Greece, May 2022 (see https://youtu.be/MG3l5v8FFbc).

We also have worked on the design and implementation of a telematic project, using this approach, called "Wind and Breath", with Wendy Wischer. This resultant installation has been accepted and will be presented at Locust Projects in Miami, FL this coming year.

Several refereed publications have also been produced.
